title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" proposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress lobbying. The amendment to Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, prohibits former Senators, Members of the House, or elected officers from influencing current members or employees of Congress on behalf of others. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" proposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress lobbying. The amendment to Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, prohibits former Senators, Members of the House, or elected officers from influencing current members or employees of Congress on behalf of others. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 207(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 3 amends the duration of restrictions for Congressional staff. SEC. 4 introduces a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database. SEC. 5 addresses the issue of the lobbyist revolving door to Congress. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving that position, unless waived by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct for a compelling national need. Lobbying contacts must be related to pending legislative business to be considered substantial. When determining if a registered lobbyist or foreign agent has had substantial lobbying contact within a certain period, Congress must consider if the contacts were related to pending legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising beyond personal contributions. Simple social contacts with Congress members or staff do not count as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate any employees or individuals under contract who are former members of Congress or congressional staff with specific criteria. Substantial lobbying entities are required to annually report employees or individuals under contract who are former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria. The filing must include a brief job description and work experience of each individual, along with improved reporting on a Joint Web site maintained by the Secretary of the Senate. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will have a database for 'Substantial Lobbying Entities' with employee job descriptions and work experience. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings to the District of Columbia US Attorney for oversight. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia US Attorney for oversight, to ensure accurate reporting of federal lobbying activities by entities with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
